context: More importantly, experiments to test cause–effect hypotheses have sometimes ignored the simple chemistry of water-soluble gases, and may have inferred incorrect conclusions as a result. In open systems, for example, there is likely to be a loss of volatile solutes from artificially applied solutions (as simulated rain or mist) that may give rise to unrealistically high concentrations, up to ppmv levels. The released vapor may then enter stomata directly, a pathway that is probably not available to solutions in the absence of surfactants (Schönherr and Bukovac, 1972), and confound the objectives of the experiment. Although weak acid solutes such as bisulfite or nitrite have obvious related gas phases such as SO2 or HNO2, even highly soluble solutes such as nitric acid or ammonia may be released as vapors as droplets evaporate (Milford et al., 2000).The role of photolysis The active role of UV light in aquatic systems is recognized as driving much of the chemistry that occurs in the uppermost surface layers of both marine and freshwater ecosystems (Cooper and Zika, 1987). However, the potential role for UV light to interact with terrestrial ecosystems has been largely ignored. Most studies of effects to date have been conducted in laboratories or controlled environment chambers, often under glass or plastic even if natural light is used. Commercial greenhouse glazing and most plastics do not transmit UV light effectively.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, sulfur dioxide (SO2) and hydrogen sulfite (bisulfite) are related through their roles as water-soluble gases and weak acid solutes. The text discusses how SO2 can exist in gas phase and interact with solutions, potentially forming bisulfite in aqueous environments. This relationship highlights the chemical dynamics between these two compounds, particularly in the context of environmental chemistry and their behavior in ecosystems.
